title: A Theorem on Analytic Strong Multiplicity One

title_detail.value: A Theorem on Analytic Strong Multiplicity One

summary:
Let $K$ be an algebraic number field, and $\pi=\otimes\pi_{v}$ an
irreducible, automorphic, cuspidal representation of $\GL_{m}(\mathbb{A}_{K})$
with analytic conductor $C(\pi)$. The theorem on analytic strong multiplicity
one established in this note states, essentially, that there exists a positive
constant $c$ depending on $\varepsilon>0, m,$ and $K$ only, such that $\pi$ can
be decided completely by its local components $\pi_{v}$ with norm $N(v)<c\cdot
C(\pi)^{2m+\varepsilon}.$

summary_detail.value:
Let $K$ be an algebraic number field, and $\pi=\otimes\pi_{v}$ an
irreducible, automorphic, cuspidal representation of $\GL_{m}(\mathbb{A}_{K})$
with analytic conductor $C(\pi)$. The theorem on analytic strong multiplicity
one established in this note states, essentially, that there exists a positive
constant $c$ depending on $\varepsilon>0, m,$ and $K$ only, such that $\pi$ can
be decided completely by its local components $\pi_{v}$ with norm $N(v)<c\cdot
C(\pi)^{2m+\varepsilon}.$

author: Yonghui Wang
fulltext:
A THEOREM ON ANALYTIC STRONG MULTIPLICITY ONE

arXiv:0812.1969v1 [math.NT] 10 Dec 2008

Jianya Liu1 & Yonghui Wang2

Abstract
Let K be an algebraic number field, and π = ⊗πv an irreducible, automorphic, cuspidal representation of GLm (AK ) with analytic conductor C(π). The theorem on analytic strong multiplicity one established in this note states, essentially, that there exists a positive constant
c depending on ε > 0, m, and K only, such that π can be decided completely by its local
components πv with norm N (v) < c * C(π)2m+ε .
2000 Mathematics Subject Classification. 11F70, 11S40, 11F67.

1. Introduction
Let K be an algebraic number field, let π and π ′ be two cuspidal automorphic representations
of GLm (AK ) with restricted tensor product decompositions π = ⊗πv and π ′ = ⊗πv′ . The strong
multiplicity one theorem states that if πv ∼
= πv′ for all but finitely many places v, then π = π ′ .
The reader is referred to [1] for history and references in this direction.
The analytic version of the above theorem gives, in terms of the analytic conductor C(π) of π
defined in (2.14), more precise information on the number of places needed to decide a cuspidal
automorphic representation π of GLm (AK ). Such an analytic result was first established by
Moreno [10], by applying zero-free regions of the Rankin-Selberg L-function of two automorphic
representations. To state the result, let Bm (Q) denote the set of all cuspidal automorphic
representations π on GLm (AK ) with analytic conductors C(π) less than a large real number Q.
Suppose that π = ⊗πv and π ′ = ⊗πv′ are in Bm (Q) with m ≥ 2. Then, according to [10], there
exist positive constants c and d such that, if πv ∼
= πv′ for all finite places v with norm

cQd ,
for m = 2,
(1.1)
N (v) ≤
2
c exp(d log Q), for m ≥ 3,
then π = π ′ .

Supported in part by the 973 Program #2007CB807900-2007CB807903, and by NSFC Grant # 10601034.

actually gives the acceptable value

(1.5)

π on GLm (AK ), with 1 ≤ m ≤ M , whose analytic conductors C(π) are less than a large real
number Q. Thus,

and the main result of this note can be stated as follows.
Theorem. Let π = ⊗πv and π ′ = ⊗πv′ be in AM (Q). Then there exists a constant c =
c(ε, M, K) depending on ε > 0, M, and K only, such that if πv ∼
= πv′ for all finite places with
norm
N (v) < cQ2M +ε
then π = π ′ .
To prove the Theorem, we will exploit, among other things, Landau's classical idea in [7].
2. Preliminaries on automorphic L-functions
In this section, we summarize some basic properties of automorphic L-functions, which will
be used in the proof of the Theorem in §3.
Let K be an algebraic number field of degree [K : Q] = l, with adèle ring AK = K∞ × AK,f ,
where K∞ is the product of the Archimedean completions of K, and the ring AK,f of finite adèles
is a restricted direct product of the completions Kv over non-Archimedean places v. Suppose

3. Proof of the Theorem
Let π = ⊗πv and π ′ = ⊗πv′ be in AM (Q). If they are twisted equivalent, i.e. π = π ′ ⊗ | det |iτ
for some τ ∈ R× , then πv ∼
6 πv′ for all finite places v with at most one exception. We may
=
therefore suppose that, for all τ ∈ R,
π 6= π ′ ⊗ | det |iτ .

(3.1)

Dirichlet series expansion (2.8), which holds for σ > 1. By (3.1), the functions L(s, π × π̃ ′ ) and
L(s, πf × π̃f′ ) are entire fucntions in the whole complex plane. Define

and now the constant c depends on ε, M, K. The assertion of the theorem finally follows from
this and (2.15).

(4.3)

Now we give a remark about the structure of C(m, m′ ). For j = 1, * * * , mm′ l, denote by
β(j) the fractional part of v(j). In addition we let β(0) = 0 and β(mm′ l + 1) = 1. Then all
β(j) ∈ [0, 1], and hence there exist β(j1 ), β(j2 ) such that β(j2 ) − β(j1 ) ≥ 1/(3mm′ l) and there is
no β(j) lying between β(j1 ) and β(j2 ). It follows that the strip S0 = {s : β(j1 ) + 1/(8mm′ l) ≤
Rs ≤ β(j2 ) − 1/(8mm′ l)} is contained in C(m, m′ ). Consequently, for all n = 0, 1, 2, * * * , the
